intro: Loranthos polyrrhizum, commonly known as the Indian mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily in the family Rutaceae. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while still performing some photosynthesis using its modified leaves. The plant produces small, white or yellowish flowers and red berries that contain seeds. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, including India, China, and Southeast Asia. Its parasitic nature and unique ecological role make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
